title: Cell Metabolism and Energy
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Investigating how cells obtain and use energy. Understanding ATP as the energy currency, the role of cellular respiration, and the importance of metabolic pathways in sustaining cellular activities.
learningIntentions: Students can explain ATP as the universal energy currency of cells and describe the ATP-ADP cycle.
Students can outline the main stages of cellular respiration and their locations within the cell.
Students can analyse the relationship between cellular structure and metabolic function, particularly in mitochondria.

engagementHook.title: The Currency of Life
engagementHook.content: Your body manufactures and consumes approximately 60 kilograms of ATP every single day—more than your own body weight. Yet you only have about 50 grams at any given moment. This constant recycling is the engine of life, powering everything from muscle contractions to nerve impulses. Today we explore how cells generate this vital energy currency.

keyConcepts.definition: The primary energy currency of cells, consisting of adenine, ribose, and three phosphate groups. Energy is released when the terminal phosphate bond is broken.
The continuous process of ATP hydrolysis (releasing energy) and ATP synthesis (storing energy) that maintains cellular energy supply.
The metabolic process that converts glucose and oxygen into ATP, carbon dioxide, and water through glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation.
The first stage of cellular respiration occurring in the cytoplasm, breaking glucose into two pyruvate molecules and producing a small amount of ATP.
The final stage of cellular respiration occurring in the inner mitochondrial membrane, producing the majority of ATP through the electron transport chain.

contentSections.title: ATP: The Energy Currency
contentSections.content: ATP consists of adenine (a nitrogenous base), ribose (a five-carbon sugar), and three phosphate groups. The high-energy bonds between phosphate groups store chemical energy that powers cellular work.
keyPoints: Breaking the terminal phosphate bond releases ~30.5 kJ/mol
ATP becomes ADP (adenosine diphosphate) after energy release
ATP synthase rebuilds ATP from ADP + phosphate
contentSections.example: Muscle contraction uses ATP to power actin-myosin interactions.

contentSections.title: Cellular Respiration Overview
contentSections.content:
Cellular respiration is the process by which cells extract energy from glucose and store it in ATP. The overall equation is:

C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + ATP

The process occurs in three main stages:

  • Glycolysis: Occurs in the cytoplasm; splits glucose into pyruvate; produces 2 ATP net.
  • Krebs Cycle (Citric Acid Cycle): Occurs in the mitochondrial matrix; produces electron carriers (NADH, FADH₂).
  • Oxidative Phosphorylation: Occurs at the inner mitochondrial membrane; produces ~28-34 ATP through the electron transport chain.

contentSections.title: Mitochondria: Powerhouse Structure
contentSections.content: The structure of mitochondria is specialised for ATP production. The inner membrane is highly folded into cristae, providing extensive surface area for the electron transport chain and ATP synthase complexes.
keyPoints: Outer membrane: Permeable to small molecules
Inner membrane: Contains electron transport proteins
Cristae: Folded membranes maximising surface area
Matrix: Contains enzymes for Krebs cycle
contentSections.example: Muscle cells have thousands of mitochondria due to high energy demands.
